awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Applying the Tools of Physics to Explore the Macroscopic, Microscopic, and Quantum Worlds
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the renewal of the Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site at the University of Illinois in Urbana-Champaign (UIUC). Each year, 12 undergraduate students will engage in hands-on, cutting-edge physics research. These students will work with senior faculty on forefront research projects in a variety of physics subdisciplines, with topics ranging from mapping the phase diagram of exotic superconductors, to determining the atomic-scale structure of DNA origami objects, to designing radiation-hard calorimeter components for the ATLAS experiment at the Large Hadron Collider. In addition to learning advanced research methods and gaining physics insight, the REU students will receive training in technical communications, teamwork, and leadership skills and receive graduate-school and career guidance.

The REU students will be integrated into senior-faculty-led research groups and contribute to on-going research projects in a variety of physics areas. The REU projects at UIUC are neither "cookbook" exercises nor simple manual labor. Students will have opportunities to write code that is subsequently used in real experiments, simulate and test components for real instruments, build and characterize novel devices, grow samples that are used in original research, and analyze real data. They will be exposed to principles of the responsible conduct of research and data management and preservation. They will receive instruction in professional technical communication skills and practice leadership and teamwork skills essential to their success as future scientists and engineers. They will experience a holistic program that teaches them not only how to do physics research, but also how to be successful physicists. This site is supported by the Department of Defense in partnership with the NSF REU program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
During the course of this project, 42 talented undergraduate students undertook independent hands-on research projects. They learned how to grow and analyze exotic superconductors, wrote code that was used in data analysis for high-energy physics experiments at Fermilab and the Large Hadron Collider, and built detectors for nuclear physics and observational cosmology experiments. One student was able to combine his love of physics and computer coding by doing developing a software simulation package to better understand how environmental stressors affect fiber optic sensors. Another combined her interest in physics and passion for astronomy by studying the impact of the Starlink satellite constellation on discovering new objects on the solar system using the Large Synoptic Survey Telescope (LSST). 

Three international students, two from Brazil, and one from India who were not supported by the National Science Foundation, participated in the program to add an international dimension to the experience for the US students. 

Every student gave at least three talks and wrote a final paper on his or her research project and received detailed oral and written feedback on their work.

Programmatic activities included a four-day orientation "boot camp" during the first week of the eight-week sessions that covered lab safety, responsible conduct of research, tutorials on scientific software and literature searches, and discussions of how to select and apply to graduate programs in physics and related disciplines. Additional workshops were held during the program and included presentations on campus safety, sexual harassment and gender bias, creating and presenting scientific posters, giving science talks, and writing scientific articles for publication. At least two students per year receive support to present their work at national conferences.  

A total of 22 faculty participated in the program; several took students all three years of the project and most participated in at least two of the three years. Faculty ranged from senior professors who are members of the National Academy of Sciences to assistant professors who are building their labs, but all were committed to the success of their students. In addition, each student was paired with a senior graduate student or postdoctoral researcher who served as a mentor, providing an additional layer of support for the student.

Great efforts were made to recruit a diverse cohort, with special emphasis given to including students from smaller colleges, those from backgrounds historically underrepresented in physics, and first-generation college students. In all, 47% of the participants were women, and 62% came from small colleges or universities with limited research programs in physics. In terms of demographics, 12% were Hispanic, 14% were African American, and 31% were first-generation college students. Of the students from the 2020?2022 programs who have graduated, fourteen are enrolled in graduate programs in physics, applied physics, chemical physics, electrical engineering, astronautical engineering or related areas UIUC [6], Stanford [1], U. of Maryland College Park [1], New York U. [1], CalTech [1], Johns Hopkins [1], University of Southern California [1], Rice University [1], and UT-Austin [1].  Two are working in research careers as a Research Technician and Software Engineering, and one is working as a Laboratory Coordinator at a university.
